templates.name: Template Module EtherLike-MIB SNMPv2
templates.description:
Template EtherLike-MIB (duplex control only)

MIBs used:
EtherLike-MIB

Template tooling version used: 0.32

discovery_rules.name: EtherLike-MIB Discovery
discovery_rules.description: Discovering interfaces from IF-MIB and EtherLike-MIB. Interfaces with up(1) Operational Status are discovered.

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Duplex status
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: EtherLike-MIB
The current mode of operation of the MAC
entity.  'unknown' indicates that the current
duplex mode could not be determined.

Management control of the duplex mode is
accomplished through the MAU MIB.  When
an interface does not support autonegotiation,
or when autonegotiation is not enabled, the
duplex mode is controlled using
ifMauDefaultType.  When autonegotiation is
supported and enabled, duplex mode is controlled
using ifMauAutoNegAdvertisedBits.  In either
case, the currently operating duplex mode is
reflected both in this object and in ifMauType.

Note that this object provides redundant
information with ifMauType.  Normally, redundant
objects are discouraged.  However, in this
instance, it allows a management application to
determine the duplex status of an interface
without having to know every possible value of
ifMauType.  This was felt to be sufficiently
valuable to justify the redundancy.
Reference: [IEEE 802.3 Std.], 30.3.1.1.32,aDuplexStatus.

trigger_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): In half-duplex mode
trigger_prototypes.description: Please check autonegotiation settings and cabling

templates.name: Template Module Generic SNMPv2
templates.description:
Template Module Generic

MIBs used:
SNMPv2-MIB

Template tooling version used: 0.32

items.name: SNMP traps (fallback)
items.description: Item is used to collect all SNMP traps unmatched by other snmptrap items

items.name: System contact details
items.description:
MIB: SNMPv2-MIB
The textual identification of the contact person for this managed node, together with information on how to contact this person.  If no contact information is known, the value is the zero-length string.

items.name: System description
items.description:
MIB: SNMPv2-MIB
A textual description of the entity. This value should
include the full name and version identification of the system's hardware type, software operating-system, and
networking software.

items.name: System location
items.description:
MIB: SNMPv2-MIB
The physical location of this node (e.g., `telephone closet, 3rd floor').  If the location is unknown, the value is the zero-length string.

items.name: System name
items.description:
MIB: SNMPv2-MIB
An administratively-assigned name for this managed node.By convention, this is the node's fully-qualified domain name.  If the name is unknown, the value is the zero-length string.

triggers.expression: (last(/Template Module Generic SNMPv2/system.name,#1)<>last(/Template Module Generic SNMPv2/system.name,#2))=1 and length(last(/Template Module Generic SNMPv2/system.name))>0
triggers.name: Systen name has changed (new name: {ITEM.VALUE})
triggers.description: System name has changed. Ack to close.

items.name: System object ID
items.description:
MIB: SNMPv2-MIB
The vendor's authoritative identification of the network management subsystem contained in the entity.  This value is allocated within the SMI enterprises subtree (1.3.6.1.4.1) and provides an easy and unambiguous means for determining`what kind of box' is being managed.  For example, if vendor`Flintstones, Inc.' was assigned the subtree1.3.6.1.4.1.4242, it could assign the identifier 1.3.6.1.4.1.4242.1.1 to its `Fred Router'.

items.name: Uptime
items.description:
MIB: SNMPv2-MIB
The time (in hundredths of a second) since the network management portion of the system was last re-initialized.

triggers.name: No SNMP data collection
triggers.description: SNMP is not available for polling. Please check device connectivity and SNMP settings.

templates.name: Template Module ICMP Ping
templates.description:
Template Module ICMP Ping

Template tooling version used: 0.32

triggers.name: Unavailable by ICMP ping
triggers.description: Last three attempts returned timeout.  Please check device connectivity.

triggers.expression: min(/Template Module ICMP Ping/icmppingloss,15m)>{$ICMP_LOSS_WARN} and min(/Template Module ICMP Ping/icmppingloss,15m)<100
triggers.name: High ICMP ping loss

dependencies.name: High ICMP ping loss
dependencies.expression: min(/Template Module ICMP Ping/icmppingloss,15m)>{$ICMP_LOSS_WARN} and min(/Template Module ICMP Ping/icmppingloss,15m)<100

templates.name: Template Module EtherLike-MIB SNMPv2
templates.description:
Template EtherLike-MIB (duplex control only)

MIBs used:
EtherLike-MIB

Template tooling version used: 0.32

discovery_rules.name: EtherLike-MIB Discovery
discovery_rules.description: Discovering interfaces from IF-MIB and EtherLike-MIB. Interfaces with up(1) Operational Status are discovered.

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Duplex status
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: EtherLike-MIB
The current mode of operation of the MAC
entity.  'unknown' indicates that the current
duplex mode could not be determined.

Management control of the duplex mode is
accomplished through the MAU MIB.  When
an interface does not support autonegotiation,
or when autonegotiation is not enabled, the
duplex mode is controlled using
ifMauDefaultType.  When autonegotiation is
supported and enabled, duplex mode is controlled
using ifMauAutoNegAdvertisedBits.  In either
case, the currently operating duplex mode is
reflected both in this object and in ifMauType.

Note that this object provides redundant
information with ifMauType.  Normally, redundant
objects are discouraged.  However, in this
instance, it allows a management application to
determine the duplex status of an interface
without having to know every possible value of
ifMauType.  This was felt to be sufficiently
valuable to justify the redundancy.
Reference: [IEEE 802.3 Std.], 30.3.1.1.32,aDuplexStatus.

trigger_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): In half-duplex mode
trigger_prototypes.description: Please check autonegotiation settings and cabling

templates.name: Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2
templates.description:
Template Module Interfaces

MIBs used:
IF-MIB

Template tooling version used: 0.32

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Inbound packets discarded
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: IF-MIB
The number of inbound packets which were chosen to be discarded
even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol.
One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system,
and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Inbound packets with errors
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: IF-MIB
For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of inbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol.  For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of inbound transmission units that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Bits received
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: IF-MIB
The total number of octets received on the interface, including framing characters. This object is a 64-bit version of ifInOctets. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Outbound packets discarded
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: IF-MIB
The number of outbound packets which were chosen to be discarded
even though no errors had been detected to prevent their being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol.
One possible reason for discarding such a packet could be to free up buffer space.
Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system,
and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Outbound packets with errors
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: IF-MIB
For packet-oriented interfaces, the number of outbound packets that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol.  For character-oriented or fixed-length interfaces, the number of outbound transmission units that contained errors preventing them from being deliverable to a higher-layer protocol. Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Bits sent
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: IF-MIB
The total number of octets transmitted out of the interface, including framing characters. This object is a 64-bit version of ifOutOctets.Discontinuities in the value of this counter can occur at re-initialization of the management system, and at other times as indicated by the value of ifCounterDiscontinuityTime.

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Speed
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: IF-MIB
An estimate of the interface's current bandwidth in units of 1,000,000 bits per second. If this object reports a value of `n' then the speed of the interface is somewhere in the range of `n-500,000' to`n+499,999'.  For interfaces which do not vary in bandwidth or for those where no accurate estimation can be made, this object should contain the nominal bandwidth. For a sub-layer which has no concept of bandwidth, this object should be zero.

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Operational status
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: IF-MIB
The current operational state of the interface.
- The testing(3) state indicates that no operational packet scan be passed
- If ifAdminStatus is down(2) then ifOperStatus should be down(2)
- If ifAdminStatus is changed to up(1) then ifOperStatus should change to up(1) if the interface is ready to transmit and receive network traffic
- It should change todormant(5) if the interface is waiting for external actions (such as a serial line waiting for an incoming connection)
- It should remain in the down(2) state if and only if there is a fault that prevents it from going to the up(1) state
- It should remain in the notPresent(6) state if the interface has missing(typically, hardware) components.

trigger_prototypes.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and (last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}])=2 and (last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1)<>last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#2))=1)
trigger_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
trigger_prototypes.description:
This trigger expression works as follows:
1. Can be triggered if operations status is down.
2. {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 - user can redefine Context macro to value - 0. That marks this interface as not important. No new trigger will be fired if this interface is down.
3. {TEMPLATE_NAME:METRIC.diff()}=1) - trigger fires only if operational status was up(1) sometime before. (So, do not fire 'ethernal off' interfaces.)

WARNING: if closed manually - won't fire again on next poll, because of .diff.

item_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Interface type
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: IF-MIB
The type of interface.
Additional values for ifType are assigned by the Internet Assigned NumbersAuthority (IANA),
through updating the syntax of the IANAifType textual convention.

trigger_prototypes.expression:
change(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}])<0 and last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}])>0
and (
last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=6 or
last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=7 or
last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=11 or
last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=62 or
last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=69 or
last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.type[ifType.{#SNMPINDEX}])=117
)
and
(last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}])<>2)
trigger_prototypes.recovery_expression:
(change(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}])>0 and last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}],#2)>0) or
(last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}])=2)
trigger_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Ethernet has changed to lower speed than it was before
trigger_prototypes.description: This Ethernet connection has transitioned down from its known maximum speed. This might be a sign of autonegotiation issues. Ack to close.

dependencies.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
dependencies.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and (last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}])=2 and (last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1)<>last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#2))=1)

trigger_prototypes.expression:
(avg(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.in[ifHCInOctets.{#SNMPINDEX}],15m)>({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}/100)*last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}]) or
avg(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.out[ifHCOutOctets.{#SNMPINDEX}],15m)>({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}/100)*last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}])) and
last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}])>0
trigger_prototypes.recovery_expression:
avg(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.in[ifHCInOctets.{#SNMPINDEX}],15m)<(({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}-3)/100)*last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}]) and
avg(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.out[ifHCOutOctets.{#SNMPINDEX}],15m)<(({$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}-3)/100)*last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.speed[ifHighSpeed.{#SNMPINDEX}])
trigger_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): High bandwidth usage ( > {$IF.UTIL.MAX:"{#IFNAME}"}% )

dependencies.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
dependencies.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and (last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}])=2 and (last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1)<>last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#2))=1)

trigger_prototypes.expression:
min(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.in.errors[ifInErrors.{#SNMPINDEX}],5m)>{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}
or min(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.out.errors[ifOutErrors.{#SNMPINDEX}],5m)>{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}
trigger_prototypes.recovery_expression:
max(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.in.errors[ifInErrors.{#SNMPINDEX}],5m)<{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}*0.8
and max(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.out.errors[ifOutErrors.{#SNMPINDEX}],5m)<{$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"}*0.8
trigger_prototypes.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): High error rate ( > {$IF.ERRORS.WARN:"{#IFNAME}"} for 5m)

dependencies.name: Interface {#IFNAME}({#IFALIAS}): Link down
dependencies.expression: {$IFCONTROL:"{#IFNAME}"}=1 and (last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}])=2 and (last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#1)<>last(/Template Module Interfaces SNMPv2/net.if.status[ifOperStatus.{#SNMPINDEX}],#2))=1)

macros.description: Filter out loopbacks, nulls, docker veth links and docker0 bridge by default

templates.template: Template Module Linux block devices SNMPv2
templates.name: Template Module Linux block devices SNMPv2
templates.description:
MIBs used:
UCD-DISKIO-MIB

Template tooling version used: 0.32

discovery_rules.name: Block devices discovery
discovery_rules.description: Block devices are discovered from UCD-DISKIO-MIB::diskIOTable (http://net-snmp.sourceforge.net/docs/mibs/ucdDiskIOMIB.html#diskIOTable)

item_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk read rate
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: UCD-DISKIO-MIB
The number of read accesses from this device since boot.

item_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk utilization
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: UCD-DISKIO-MIB
The 1 minute average load of disk (%)

item_prototypes.name: {#DEVNAME}: Disk write rate
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: UCD-DISKIO-MIB
The number of write accesses from this device since boot.

item.host: Template Module Linux block devices SNMPv2
Template Module Linux block devices SNMPv2

macros.description: This macro is used in block devices discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level
This macro is used in block devices discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level

templates.name: Template Module Linux CPU SNMPv2
templates.description:
MIBs used:
HOST-RESOURCES-MIB
UCD-SNMP-MIB

Template tooling version used: 0.32

items.name: Load average (1m avg)
items.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB

items.name: Load average (5m avg)
items.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB

items.name: Load average (15m avg)
items.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB

items.name: Number of CPUs
items.description:
MIB: HOST-RESOURCES-MIB
Count the number of CPU cores by counting number of cores discovered in hrProcessorTable using LLD

parameters:
//count the number of cores
return JSON.parse(value).length;

discovery_rules.name: CPU discovery
discovery_rules.description: This discovery will create set of per core CPU metrics from UCD-SNMP-MIB, using {#CPU.COUNT} in preprocessing. That's the only reason why LLD is used.

item_prototypes.name: CPU guest time
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB
Guest  time (time  spent  running  a  virtual  CPU  for  a  guest  operating  system)

parameters:
//to get utilization in %, divide by N, where N is number of cores.
return value/{#CPU.COUNT}

item_prototypes.name: CPU guest nice time
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB
Time spent running a niced guest (virtual CPU for guest operating systems under the control of the Linux kernel)

parameters:
//to get utilization in %, divide by N, where N is number of cores.
return value/{#CPU.COUNT}

item_prototypes.name: CPU idle time
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB
The time the CPU has spent doing nothing.

parameters:
//to get utilization in %, divide by N, where N is number of cores.
return value/{#CPU.COUNT}

item_prototypes.name: CPU interrupt time
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB
The amount of time the CPU has been servicing hardware interrupts.

parameters:
//to get utilization in %, divide by N, where N is number of cores.
return value/{#CPU.COUNT}

item_prototypes.name: CPU iowait time
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB
Amount of time the CPU has been waiting for I/O to complete.

parameters:
//to get utilization in %, divide by N, where N is number of cores.
return value/{#CPU.COUNT}

item_prototypes.name: CPU nice time
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB
The time the CPU has spent running users' processes that have been niced.

parameters:
//to get utilization in %, divide by N, where N is number of cores.
return value/{#CPU.COUNT}

item_prototypes.name: CPU softirq time
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB
The amount of time the CPU has been servicing software interrupts.

parameters:
//to get utilization in %, divide by N, where N is number of cores.
return value/{#CPU.COUNT}

item_prototypes.name: CPU steal time
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB
The amount of CPU 'stolen' from this virtual machine by the hypervisor for other tasks (such as running another virtual machine).

parameters:
//to get utilization in %, divide by N, where N is number of cores.
return value/{#CPU.COUNT}

item_prototypes.name: CPU system time
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB
The time the CPU has spent running the kernel and its processes.

parameters:
//to get utilization in %, divide by N, where N is number of cores.
return value/{#CPU.COUNT}

item_prototypes.name: CPU user time
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB
The time the CPU has spent running users' processes that are not niced.

parameters:
//to get utilization in %, divide by N, where N is number of cores.
return value/{#CPU.COUNT}

item_prototypes.name: CPU utilization
item_prototypes.description: CPU utilization in %

parameters:
//count the number of CPU cores
return JSON.stringify([{"{#CPU.COUNT}": value, "{#SNMPINDEX}": 0, "{#SINGLETON}":""}])

macros.description: Load per CPU considered sustainable. Tune if needed.

templates.name: Template Module Linux filesystems SNMPv2
templates.description:
MIBs used:
HOST-RESOURCES-MIB
UCD-SNMP-MIB

Template tooling version used: 0.32

item_prototypes.name: {#FSNAME}: Free inodes in %
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB
If having problems collecting this item make sure access to UCD-SNMP-MIB is allowed.

trigger_prototypes.name: {#FSNAME}: Running out of free inodes (free < {$VFS.FS.INODE.PFREE.MIN.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}%)
trigger_prototypes.description:
It may become impossible to write to disk if there are no index nodes left.
As symptoms, 'No space left on device' or 'Disk is full' errors may be seen even though free space is available.

trigger_prototypes.name: {#FSNAME}: Running out of free inodes (free < {$VFS.FS.INODE.PFREE.MIN.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"}%)
trigger_prototypes.description:
It may become impossible to write to disk if there are no index nodes left.
As symptoms, 'No space left on device' or 'Disk is full' errors may be seen even though free space is available.

item_prototypes.name: {#FSNAME}: Space utilization
item_prototypes.description: Space utilization in % for {#FSNAME}

item_prototypes.name: {#FSNAME}: Total space
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: HOST-RESOURCES-MIB
The size of the storage represented by this entry, in units of hrStorageAllocationUnits.
This object is writable to allow remote configuration of the size of the storage area in those cases where such an operation makes sense and is possible on the underlying system.
For example, the amount of main storage allocated to a buffer pool might be modified or the amount of disk space allocated to virtual storage might be modified.

item_prototypes.name: {#FSNAME}: Used space
item_prototypes.description:
MIB: HOST-RESOURCES-MIB
The amount of the storage represented by this entry that is allocated, in units of hrStorageAllocationUnits.

trigger_prototypes.expression:
last(/Template Module Linux filesystems SNMPv2/vfs.fs.pused[storageUsedPercentage.{#SNMPINDEX}])>{$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"} and
((last(/Template Module Linux filesystems SNMPv2/vfs.fs.total[hrStorageSize.{#SNMPINDEX}])-last(/Template Module Linux filesystems SNMPv2/vfs.fs.used[hrStorageUsed.{#SNMPINDEX}]))<5G or timeleft(/Template Module Linux filesystems SNMPv2/vfs.fs.pused[storageUsedPercentage.{#SNMPINDEX}],1h,100)<1d)
trigger_prototypes.name: {#FSNAME}: Disk space is critically low (used > {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}%)
trigger_prototypes.description:
Two conditions should match: First, space utilization should be above {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}.
 Second condition should be one of the following:
 - The disk free space is less than 5G.
 - The disk will be full in less than 24 hours.

trigger_prototypes.expression:
last(/Template Module Linux filesystems SNMPv2/vfs.fs.pused[storageUsedPercentage.{#SNMPINDEX}])>{$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"} and
((last(/Template Module Linux filesystems SNMPv2/vfs.fs.total[hrStorageSize.{#SNMPINDEX}])-last(/Template Module Linux filesystems SNMPv2/vfs.fs.used[hrStorageUsed.{#SNMPINDEX}]))<10G or timeleft(/Template Module Linux filesystems SNMPv2/vfs.fs.pused[storageUsedPercentage.{#SNMPINDEX}],1h,100)<1d)
trigger_prototypes.name: {#FSNAME}: Disk space is low (used > {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.WARN:"{#FSNAME}"}%)
trigger_prototypes.description:
Two conditions should match: First, space utilization should be above {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}.
 Second condition should be one of the following:
 - The disk free space is less than 10G.
 - The disk will be full in less than 24 hours.

dependencies.name: {#FSNAME}: Disk space is critically low (used > {$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"}%)
dependencies.expression:
last(/Template Module Linux filesystems SNMPv2/vfs.fs.pused[storageUsedPercentage.{#SNMPINDEX}])>{$VFS.FS.PUSED.MAX.CRIT:"{#FSNAME}"} and
((last(/Template Module Linux filesystems SNMPv2/vfs.fs.total[hrStorageSize.{#SNMPINDEX}])-last(/Template Module Linux filesystems SNMPv2/vfs.fs.used[hrStorageUsed.{#SNMPINDEX}]))<5G or timeleft(/Template Module Linux filesystems SNMPv2/vfs.fs.pused[storageUsedPercentage.{#SNMPINDEX}],1h,100)<1d)

macros.description: This macro is used in filesystems discovery. Can be overridden on the host or linked template level

templates.name: Template Module Linux memory SNMPv2
templates.description:
MIBs used:
UCD-SNMP-MIB

Known Issues:

  Description: Please note that memory utilization is a rough estimate, since memory available is calculated as free+buffers+cached, which is not 100% accurate, but the best we can get using SNMP.

Template tooling version used: 0.32

items.name: Free swap space
items.description:
MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB
The amount of swap space currently unused or available.

items.name: Total swap space
items.description:
MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB
The total amount of swap space configured for this host.

items.name: Available memory
items.description: Please note that memory utilization is a rough estimate, since memory available is calculated as free+buffers+cached, which is not 100% accurate, but the best we can get using SNMP.

items.name: Memory (buffers)
items.description:
MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB
Memory used by kernel buffers (Buffers in /proc/meminfo)

items.name: Memory (cached)
items.description:
MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB
Memory used by the page cache and slabs (Cached and Slab in /proc/meminfo)

items.name: Free memory
items.description: MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB

items.name: Total memory
items.description:
MIB: UCD-SNMP-MIB
Total memory in Bytes

items.name: Memory utilization
items.description: Please note that memory utilization is a rough estimate, since memory available is calculated as free+buffers+cached, which is not 100% accurate, but the best we can get using SNMP.

dependencies.name: Lack of available memory ( < {$MEMORY.AVAILABLE.MIN} of {ITEM.VALUE2})
dependencies.expression: min(/Template Module Linux memory SNMPv2/vm.memory.available[snmp],5m)<{$MEMORY.AVAILABLE.MIN} and last(/Template Module Linux memory SNMPv2/vm.memory.total[memTotalReal.0])>0

triggers.expression: min(/Template Module Linux memory SNMPv2/system.swap.pfree[snmp],5m)<{$SWAP.PFREE.MIN.WARN} and last(/Template Module Linux memory SNMPv2/system.swap.total[memTotalSwap.0])>0
triggers.name: High swap space usage ( less than {$SWAP.PFREE.MIN.WARN}% free)
triggers.description: This trigger is ignored, if there is no swap configured

dependencies.name: Lack of available memory ( < {$MEMORY.AVAILABLE.MIN} of {ITEM.VALUE2})
dependencies.expression: min(/Template Module Linux memory SNMPv2/vm.memory.available[snmp],5m)<{$MEMORY.AVAILABLE.MIN} and last(/Template Module Linux memory SNMPv2/vm.memory.total[memTotalReal.0])>0

triggers.expression: min(/Template Module Linux memory SNMPv2/vm.memory.available[snmp],5m)<{$MEMORY.AVAILABLE.MIN} and last(/Template Module Linux memory SNMPv2/vm.memory.total[memTotalReal.0])>0
triggers.name: Lack of available memory ( < {$MEMORY.AVAILABLE.MIN} of {ITEM.VALUE2})
Load average is too high (per CPU load over {$LOAD_AVG_PER_CPU.MAX.WARN} for 5m)
triggers.description: Per CPU load average is too high. Your system may be slow to respond.
